paragraphs.text: Poorly implemented overlays can hinder task completion. To ensure your modal doesn’t get in the way make sure to include the following:
paragraphs.name: e6bb

paragraphs.text: Note: Do not use to show error, success, or warning messages. Keep them on the page.
paragraphs.name: 8b28

paragraphs.text: Note: Do not use to show error, success, or warning messages. Keep them on the page.
paragraphs.name: 8b28

paragraphs.text: Location — upper half of the screen because in mobile view modal may be lost if placed lower.
paragraphs.name: a613

paragraphs.text: Modals, Overlays, Dialogs, whatever you call them it’s time to revisit this UI pattern. When they first came on the scene, modal windows were an elegant solution to a UI problem. The first being that it simplifies the UI, the second, it saves screen real estate. Since then designers have readily adopted the modal window and some have taken it to the extreme. Modals have become the today’s version of the dreaded popup window. Users find modals annoying and have been trained to instinctively and automatically dismiss these windows.
paragraphs.name: fdf5

paragraphs.text: A modal window is an element that sits on top of an application’s main window. It creates a mode that disables the main window but keeps it visible with the modal window as a child window in front of it. Users must interact with the modal window before they can return to the parent application. — Wikipedia
paragraphs.name: 50c7

paragraphs.text:
As you mentioned #3 button labels must be clear and use verbs, I agree. I apply myself the button labels must be the answers to “Would you like to ______verbs_____ ?” question. For example, “Would you like to delete the item? Then the answers would be (2 buttons) “Cancel” and “Delete.” 
The affirmation is on the right and dismissing of the modal…

I would use modeless or non-blocking modals for those messages. So I agree those messages don’t HAVE to be on the page. I was going to talk about modeless windows in my next article.

de2d3d47775c.title: Regarding the accessibility aspect of modals, I recommend using a library for this.

paragraphs.text: Regarding the accessibility aspect of modals, I recommend using a library for this. For instance, a11y-dialog. I say this because when it comes to accessibility, even a small bug in the focus logic or ARIA can make the solution virtually inaccessible, so it’s better to just rely on tools for this, I think.

paragraphs.text: I’ve gotta disagree with this. For pretty much all of GUI history, users have been conditioned to know how to use and react to error, success, and warning messages displayed as a modal window on top of what they’re doing. Every program we’ve ever used does it, and it’s a useful and well-accepted way to convey those types of messages.
